title: Learning from Outcomes
content: Decisions produce outcomes. Learning from outcomes improves future decisions. But outcome quality alone doesn't indicate decision quality—good decisions can have bad outcomes, and bad decisions can luck into good outcomes. Evaluate both the outcome and the decision process that produced it.

mcq.question: A risky decision worked out well. What should you conclude?

options.A: The decision was good since the outcome was good
options.B: Evaluate whether the decision process was sound, regardless of outcome
options.C: Take similar risks in the future

mcq.explanation: Good outcomes don't validate poor decision processes. You might have been lucky. Evaluate whether the process was sound—did you consider risks, have good information, follow appropriate methods? Process quality matters more than single outcomes.

openQuestions: When has a good outcome masked a poor decision process?
How do you evaluate decision quality separately from outcomes?
